data.title: CN113818285A - Reconstituted plant material and its use for packaging, wrapping and food utensils - Google Patents
data.meta_description: The present invention relates to reconstituted plant material and its use for packaging, wrapping and food utensils. The present invention relates to a plant-based wrapping paper for wrapping food. The plant (raw material) may be fruit, aromatic grass, medicinal plant, tea, vegetable and/or spice. The invention also relates to a method for producing said wrapping paper, to its use for wrapping food or to its use as packaging material.
data.text:
Detailed Description

In one embodiment of the present invention, there is provided a wrapper for wrapping a food product, the wrapper comprising a layer of fibrous plant product and a plant extract applied thereto. The wrapper is a plant-based composition or product, also referred to as a plant composition. Hereinafter, the above-mentioned wrapping paper is generally referred to as "wrapping paper or product of the present invention" or "product". Aromatic grass, vegetables, fruits, tea and/or spice compositions or mixtures are also referred to as "mixtures of aromatic grass and spices". These terms are used interchangeably and are not intended to limit the present invention.

The term "plant" as used herein also refers to any living organism of the kingdom Plantae and includes plants and plant parts (e.g. roots, bark, seeds, stems, leaves, flowers and fruits) described as cereals, fruits and vegetables.

In the product of the invention, the plant is for example selected from fruits, herbs, medicinal plants, tea, vegetables and/or spices, including mixtures thereof, for example mixtures of herbs with vegetables, herbs with fruits, vegetables with spices, fruits with spices or herbs with spices.

As used herein, a spice is a dried seed, fruit, root, bark or vegetable matter (vegetitive substance) used primarily for flavoring, coloring or preserving food. As used herein, herbs are any plants used for flavoring, food, pharmaceuticals or spices (perfume). Culinary use typically distinguishes herbs from "spices" (products from other parts of the plant (usually dried), including seeds, berries, bark, roots and fruits), and refers to leafy (leaf) green parts of the plant (fresh or dried).

However, in connection with the present invention relating to the term "plant", any plant part may be used, such as roots, bark, seeds, stems, leaves, flowers and fruits.

The fruit, herbs, medicinal plants, tea, vegetables and spices are for example selected from the group consisting of artemisia (artemisia), balsam (palm), basil (basil), chamomile (chamomile), chive (chive), clove (cloves), coffee (coffee), coriander (coriander), dill (dill), garlic (garlic), ginger (ginger), ginseng (ginseng), ginkgo (ginko), jasmine (jasmine), lavender (lavender), mint (mint), orange (orange blossom), oregano (oregano), parsley (persil), lewy (rooibos), rosa multiflora (rosa centifolia), rosemary (rosemarie), thyme (thyme), turmeric (turmeric), sage (sage), pepper (pepper), hot pepper (pepper), green tea (green tea), black tea (green tea), green tea (green tea, sweet (green tea, sweet, vanilla (vanilla), sargentgloryvine or greenvine (red or green vine), violet (violet) and/or willow (window).

Mixtures of two or more of the above mentioned culinary, aromatic and/or medicinal plants are also included in part of the invention, as disclosed herein.

In one embodiment of the invention, the plant is tea (Camellia sinensis), including white tea (white tea), yellow tea (yellow tea), green tea (green tea), oolong tea (oolong tea), black tea (black tea) and/or pu-erh tea, and the like, including mixtures or blends thereof.

In one embodiment, the wrapper of the present invention comprises a layer of fibrous plant product, wherein the fibrous plant product comprises a blend of different plants.

In one embodiment, the wrapper of the present invention comprises a plant extract, wherein the plant extract comprises a blend of different plants.

In another embodiment, the wrapper comprises a layer of fibrous plant product and a plant extract applied thereto, wherein the fibrous plant product comprises a blend of different plants and the plant extract also comprises a blend of different plants, or wherein the fibrous plant product comprises a single plant and the plant extract comprises a blend of different plants, or wherein the fibrous plant product comprises a blend of different plants and the plant extract comprises a single plant.

In another embodiment of the wrapper, the fibrous plant product layer and the plant extract are from the same plant or from different plants.

In one embodiment of the invention, the fibrous plant product layer of the wrapper paper comprises at least 70% (w/w), at least 80% (w/w) or at least 90% (w/w) fibrous plant product from a plant.

In one embodiment of the invention, the plant extract comprises at least 70% (w/w), at least 80% (w/w) or at least 90% (w/w) of a plant extract from a plant. In another embodiment, the wrapper comprises at least 70% fibrous plant product.

Another embodiment of the present invention relates to a method for producing the wrapping paper for wrapping food of the present invention. For example, the method comprises the steps of:

a) extracting at least one plant component with a solvent;

b) separating the soluble fraction (plant extract) from the insoluble fraction (solid plant particles);

c) optionally refining the insoluble fraction;

d) preparing a sheet-like product from the insoluble fraction;

e) optionally concentrating the soluble fraction;

f) applying the soluble fraction of step b) or the concentrated soluble fraction of step e) to the sheet of step d); and

g) drying the product of step f) to obtain said wrapper for wrapping a food product.

In one embodiment of the invention, one or more plant components (plant material or plant ingredients (finish)) such as stems, pieces (crops), leaves, fines (dust) and/or short pieces (short) are first mixed with a solvent such as water and/or other compounds at elevated temperature. For example, various solvents that are miscible with water (e.g., alcohols (e.g., ethanol)) can be combined with water to form an aqueous solvent. In some cases, the water content of the aqueous solvent may be greater than 50% by weight of the solvent. In one embodiment, the water content is 70%, 80%, 90% or 100%. Deionized, distilled or tap water may be used. The amount of solvent in the suspension can vary widely, but is typically added in an amount of from about 75% to about 99% by weight of the suspension. However, the amount of solvent may vary with the nature of the solvent, the temperature at which the extraction is carried out, and the type of plant component.

After forming the solvent/botanical ingredient mixture, some or all of the soluble extract fraction of the ingredient mixture may optionally be separated (e.g., extracted) from the mixture. If desired, the aqueous solvent/plant ingredient mixture can be agitated during extraction by stirring, shaking, or otherwise mixing the mixture in order to increase the extraction rate. Generally, the extraction is carried out for about 0.5 hours to about 6 hours. Further, typical extraction temperatures range from about 10 â to about 100 â, although not required.

An optional grinding or cutting step may be used prior to the extraction step in order to break up the plant or plant parts and thus disrupt the cell walls of the plant.

Once separated from the insoluble residue fraction of the plant solution, the soluble extract fraction may optionally be concentrated using any known type of concentrator (e.g., a vacuum evaporator). In one embodiment, the soluble component may be highly concentrated. Furthermore, the concentrated or unconcentrated soluble extract fraction may be used in any desired manner. For example, the soluble extract fraction may be used as a flavoring material or a portion may be added to the insoluble residue fraction.

Once extracted, the insoluble residue fraction may optionally be subjected to one or more mechanical refiners (mechanical refiners) to produce a fibrous slurry. Some examples of suitable refiners may include disc refiners (disc refiners), cone refiners (chemical refiners), and the like. The insoluble residue fraction may be used in any desired manner. For example, the insoluble residue fraction may be used as a flavouring material for producing the wrapper of the present invention, which is also referred to herein as reconstituted plant material.

To produce the wrapper of the present invention, the insoluble residue fraction is transferred to a paper making station (paper making station). The papermaking station includes a forming apparatus (forming wire) which may include, for example, a forming wire (forming wire), a gravity drain (gravity drain), a suction drain (suction drain), a felt press (felt press), a yankee dryer (yankee dryer), a drum dryer (drum dryer), and the like. Generally, the insoluble residue fraction may be in the form of a slurry. In the former, the slurry is placed on a mesh belt (wire belt) that forms a sheet-like shape. Excess water was removed using gravity drains, suction drains, pressure and a dryer. Thereafter, if desired, a portion of the soluble extract fraction may be reapplied to the insoluble residue fraction on one side or on both sides of the insoluble residue fraction. When the insoluble residue fraction is recombined with the soluble extract fraction, the resulting plant product is often referred to as "reconstituted plant material".

Reconstituted plant material can generally be formed in a variety of ways. For example, in one embodiment, tape casting (band casting) may be used to form the reconstituted plant material. Belt casting typically utilizes a slurry of finely divided plant parts mixed with a binder (e.g., gum arabic, guar gum, alginic acids, xanthan gum, cellulose and cellulose derivatives (e.g., carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC), hydroxypropyl methyl cellulose (HPMC)), pectin or starch), which is coated on a steel belt (steel band) and then dried. In one embodiment, the method is performed according to a process similar to conventional tobacco reconstitution processes, described, for example, in U.S. patent nos. 3,353,541, 3,420,241, 3,386,449, 3,760,815, and 4,674,519, which are incorporated herein by reference in their entirety. The process for producing the product of the present invention may also be carried out by a paper making process to reconstitute any plant components (e.g., stems, chips, leaves, fines, and/or short pieces) into a paper-like product. Some examples of such methods are described in U.S. patent nos. 3,428,053, 3,415,253, 3,561,451, 3,467,109, 3,483,874, 3,860,012, 3,847,164, 4, 182,349, 5,715,844, 5,724,998, and 5,765,570, which are also incorporated herein by reference in their entirety for all purposes. For example, forming the product of the present invention using papermaking techniques may include the steps of: mixing the fruit, herb, medicinal plant, tea, vegetable and/or spice with water, extracting soluble components therefrom, concentrating the soluble components, refining the fruit, herb, medicinal plant, tea, vegetable and/or spice to form a web, reapplying the concentrated soluble components, drying, and threshing.

In the method of the invention, more specifically, for the insoluble fraction (solid plant particles) used to provide the unimpregnated fibrous web of the invention (i.e. the sheet-like product in step d), the plant is not tobacco, wood pulp, cotton, textiles, jute flax (jute flax), Indian hemp (Indian hemp), hemp (hemp), hooping vine (hoopvine), kenaf (kenaf), nettle (nettle), ramie (rami), abaca (abac), bamboo fibre, banana (especially banana bark (banana bark)), bowstring hemp (bowstring hemp), coir (coir) (fibres from coconut shells), thatch (paratto), hennarcota (henqueen), kapok (kapok), milkweed (kweed), papaya (papaya), new zealand (new zealand), sisal (sisal), field (sisal), flax (baffea), flax (bagasse), papaya), new zealand (plum) (pineapple), pineapple (pineapple), pineapples (sisal), sisal (sisal), pine (bava), flax (baybea) or flax (bayberry), flax, kenaf (bayberry), hemp (bayberry), kenaf, f, kenaf, ken, Abelmoschus manihot (aibika) or Yucca (yucca). However, mixtures of the plants referred to herein in connection with the present invention with any of the above-mentioned plants may be used. In addition to the materials listed above, other materials may be added to improve the physical properties of the product, such as cellulose derivatives (e.g. methylcellulose, carboxymethylcellulose (CMC), Hydroxypropylmethylcellulose (HPMC)), starch and starch derivatives (e.g. oxidatively degraded starch), polysaccharides (and derivatives thereof) (e.g. pectin, gelatin, guar gum, agar, alginic acids, carrageenan) or synthetic fibers (e.g. synthetic fibers made of vinyl chloride or vinyl acetate, polyethylene, polypropylene, polyester).

Once extracted, the insoluble solids portion can optionally be passed through one or more mechanical refiners to produce a fibrous slurry. Some examples of suitable refiners may include disk refiners, cone refiners, and the like, as known to the skilled artisan. The slurry from the refiner may then be transferred to a papermaking station (not shown) that includes forming equipment, which may include, for example, a forming wire, gravity drainage, suction drainage, a felt press, a yankee dryer, a drum dryer, or the like. In such a forming apparatus, the slurry is placed on a mesh belt forming a sheet-like shape, and excess water is removed by gravity drainage and suction drainage and pressure. Once separated from the insoluble portion of the plant solution (plant extract), the soluble portion may optionally be concentrated using any known type of concentrator, such as a vacuum evaporator.

In some embodiments of the invention, a wet strength agent (wet strength agent) may be added to the fibrous portion to reduce potential degradation of the reconstituted material when the reconstituted material is in contact with a liquid (e.g., water), such as by immersion in water (infusion). Any suitable wet strength agent preferably selected for food and/or baking paper applications may be used, such as polyamide-epichlorohydrin resins, polyamine-epichlorohydrin resins, poly (aminoamide) -epichlorohydrin resins, urea-formaldehyde resins; melamine-formaldehyde resins; an alkyl ketene dimer; alkyl succinic anhydrides; a polyvinylamine; oxidized polysaccharides (e.g., oxidatively degraded starches); glyoxalated polyacrylamide resin; polyimines (e.g., polyethyleneimine). Wet strength agents are well known to the skilled person and are described in compositional Standards (Ingredients Standards), such as BFR (Federal Risk assessment research) XXXVI and BFR XXXVI/1 and BFRXXXVI/2 or FDA (food and drug administration) 21 CFR 176.170, FDA 21 CFR 176.110, FDA 21 CFR 176.120, FDA 21 CFR 176.1180. The wet strength agent is for example used in an amount of about 0.1% w/w to about 20% w/w, preferably about 1% w/w to about 10% w/w, more preferably about 5% w/w. The wet strength agent is preferably added to the fibrous portion at the time of or before the preparation of the sheet-like product (see step d) above).

In one embodiment, the water used for extraction is hot water, preferably about 30 to 100 â, 40 to 90 â or 50 to 80 â, or more preferably about 70 â.

In one embodiment, the coating ratio (coating ratio) of the soluble portion on the web is about 5% to 80% (w/w), 10% to 70% (w/w), or more preferably 20% to 50% (w/w). In some embodiments, the coating ratio or soluble portion added back to the base web (fibrous web) is similar to the portion of soluble material contained in and extracted from the original plant (the so-called "standard level").

The basis weight (base weight) of the final product can be adjusted during the manufacturing process so that it is suitable for the intended purpose. For example, in one embodiment, the basis weight of the final product may be from about 20 to about 300g/m2(dry basis), more preferably about 70g/m2To about 300g/m2. In another embodiment, the basis weight of the final product may be from about 90 to about 150g/m2For example, from about 90 to about 120g/m2ã

The extraction time depends on the fruit, herbs, medicinal plants, tea, vegetables and/or spices that are subjected to the extraction process. In one embodiment of the invention, the extraction time is about 15 to 60 minutes, preferably 45 minutes.

In one embodiment of the method of the invention, the extraction step is performed using components of a plant blend, and in another embodiment, the extraction step is performed using components of a single plant.

The extraction can also be carried out by means other than using hot water, i.e. by extraction with a supercritical gas (e.g. carbon dioxide), or by extraction using, for example, ethanol, hexane, acetone, R134a (1, 1, 1, 2-tetrafluoroethane), carbon dioxide and hydrofluorocarbons. In one embodiment, the extraction may be performed by using at least one solvent at room temperature and at atmospheric pressure. The extraction can also be carried out by using a mixture of different solvents. In another embodiment, the extraction may be performed using at least one solvent, such as R134a or carbon dioxide, at different temperatures and different pressures and different states (liquid or gaseous). For example, extraction can be performed using a solvent that is in a liquid state (e.g., a solvent that is volatile or non-volatile at room temperature), in a subcritical state (e.g., water at a temperature above 100 â and a pressure above 1 bar), or in a supercritical state (e.g., carbon dioxide at a temperature above 31 â and a pressure above 73 bar).

Certain plants may require specific extraction conditions (time, temperature, solid/liquid ratio) due to the ingredients contained therein, which may be temperature sensitive or must not be subjected to certain extraction conditions. For example, lycopene is extracted from tomato, and we must release the product from tomato cells by using specific enzymes. In connection with the present invention, processing aids may be used to improve extraction, such as pH adjusting agents (e.g. NaOH or organic acids), microwaves, pressure, ultrasound, enzymes (e.g. proteases, amylases, cellulases and/or pectinases). Whenever reference is made herein to "extraction," the term includes the alternative extraction approaches described above. The extraction used in connection with the present invention may be performed in continuous or discontinuous events. Extraction conditions are well known to the skilled worker and are described in standard textbooks, for example Handbook of Separation technologies for Chemical Engineers, third edition (March 1997), Philip A.Schweitzer, McGraw-Hill Inc.

In one embodiment, the extraction and/or pressing (pressing) may be performed using at least a portion of plant material that is fresh, frozen or dried, or selected from roots, bark, seeds, stems, leaves, flowers and fruits.

The separation of the soluble fraction (plant extract) from the insoluble fraction (solid plant particles) can be carried out by separating the liquid phase from the solid phase, for example by filtration with or without pressure, by centrifugation or other methods commonly used in laboratories and well known to the skilled person.

In one embodiment of the method of using a mixture or blend of plants, the insoluble portion of the plant is mixed with the insoluble portion of at least one other plant prior to preparing the tablet.

Certain embodiments of the methods of the present invention use the soluble fraction of step b) or the concentrated soluble fraction of step e) mixed with the soluble fraction or concentrated soluble fraction of at least one other plant prior to applying the soluble fraction or concentrated soluble fraction to the sheet.

For certain applications, it is desirable to condition the composition by adding or removing ingredients or components to or from the plant extract and/or insoluble plant particles prior to producing the final product of the present invention. Such adjustments may be made to modify/improve the chemical, physical and/or organoleptic properties of the finished product. Accordingly, the present invention encompasses a method further comprising the steps of: adding or removing ingredients from the soluble fraction (plant extract) and/or from the insoluble fraction (solid plant particles) before applying the soluble fraction of step b) or the concentrated soluble fraction of step e) to the sheet of step d).

In some embodiments, the sheet or sheet-like product obtained in step g) may be provided as a web or a fibrous web. The sheet-like product or web may be used in different sizes and shapes. For example, in one embodiment of the invention, the web or web may be rolled up on a reel (real) or spool (spool) so that the user can unwind the necessary size of the web or web and cut it to any suitable size. Alternatively, the composition is brought or formed into any desired shape, size and form, such as a sheet (sheet), leaf (leaf) (or leaf-like shape), stick (stick), band (band), cup (cup), jar (mug), bag (bag), convenience pack (palillote), bowl (bowl), flask (flash), jug (button), bottle (bottle), etc., straw (straw) or tube (tube), disc (disc) or sheet, etc. In one embodiment, the wrapper may be in the form of a sheet, foil (foil), pouch, as a box and/or convenient packaging.

In addition to cutting or breaking the sheet or web into a desired size and/or shape or forming it into a desired size and/or shape, it may also be dried to a desired final moisture content.

In some embodiments of the invention, the web further comprises coating (coating) or impregnation (impregnation) with soluble parts of vegetables, fruits, herbs, medicinal plants or tea (plant extracts). In one embodiment, the present invention relates to the use of a wrapper for treating a food product. Treatment in the sense of the present invention means any contact between the wrapper and the food product. For example, treating the food product involves wrapping, covering or packaging the food product with a wrapper, but is not limited thereto. In one embodiment, "covering" describes a less tightly wrapped package, such as simply covering or placing a food item on a wrapper. An example of such covering or simply placing food thereon is, but is not limited to, use as conventional baking paper, which generally contacts only one side of the food item placed directly on the baking paper.

During processing, the food product may be seasoned, as will be explained in more detail below. Thus, another embodiment of the present invention relates to the use of a wrapper for flavoring a food product. By "flavouring" in the sense of the present invention is meant the transfer or provision of a particular aroma, flavour and/or taste to a food treated with a wrapper. The seasoning process will generally be carried out in the manner described below for wrapping food items with a wrapper.

The invention relates in particular to the use of a wrapper for wrapping a food product. In the sense of the present invention, the term "wrapper" includes any form of paper and any use thereof suitable for flavouring food products. For example, the wrapper may be used as a conventional baking paper as described above, or for lightly and/or tightly wrapping a food item, or may be provided in the form of a pouch, convenient pack or box, or any other suitable form as described below. When used as a bag, convenience pack or box, the food product may be placed in the bag, convenience pack or box. In general, there is no limitation as to the manner in which the wrapper may be used, i.e., in a folded or unfolded manner, or for what flavoring purposes.

In one embodiment of the invention, the wrapper is used to release and/or transfer the aroma, flavor and/or taste of fruits, herbs, medicinal plants, tea, vegetables and/or spices to the food wrapped therewith. This is done in order to provide a specific aroma, flavor and/or taste to the food product that supports and/or modifies the natural taste or flavor of the food product. The wrapper serves as a carrier for the respective aroma, flavor and/or taste (as described above) and transfers it to the food product wrapped with the wrapper of the present invention. The transfer of aroma, flavor and/or taste or by direct contact of the wrapper and the food product without any further processing; or alternatively by further processing the coated food product, e.g., by cooking, frying, roasting, grilling, baking the coated food product, and the like. In the sense of the present invention, "without further processing" means that the wrapping paper wraps the food and is stored for a specific time.

In another embodiment of the invention, different wrappers are used to wrap the food product at the same time to provide different flavors and/or tastes to the food product. As mentioned above, it is also possible to combine different fragrances for the wrapper itself, depending on the respective production method. The specific combination of flavors can be adjusted depending on the food product that should be coated and therefore flavored.

In another embodiment of the invention, a wrapper may be used to change the color of the food product in addition to the flavoring purpose. The coloring properties depend on the materials used in the wrapper, i.e. the fibrous plant product and the plant extract applied thereto. In addition, the original color of the food product affects the final color of the food product treated with the wrapper. Different colors of the food can also be obtained if different wrappers are used simultaneously in the packaging process.

Generally, any kind of food which should have an altered or improved aroma, flavor and/or taste can be packaged with the wrapper of the present invention. For example, the food that can be packaged with the wrapping paper of the present invention can be selected from meat, fish, cheese, baked goods, insects, vegetables, fruits, and the like.

The meat may be used in any suitable form, such as, but not limited to, sliced, sausage form, cut into small pieces, as a rotisserie (roast), and the like.

In addition to the above-described food products, additional ingredients necessary or desirable for preparing the food product may be added prior to coating the food product. The additional ingredient may be selected from, but not limited to, cream, yogurt, curd, cheese, ketchup, and/or mustard. The additional ingredients may be applied directly to the wrapper or may be wrapped with the corresponding food product.

The wrapping paper according to the present invention can be used for wrapping food. Depending on the purpose of wrapping the food product, the wrapping process may result in only a loose wrap or a relatively tight wrap of the food product to bring the food product into close contact with the wrapper. For example, the wrapper may be in the form of a sheet, leaf (or leaf-like shape), strip, tape, cup, jar, pouch, convenience pack, box, case, cylinder, bowl, flask, pot, bottle, etc., straw or tube, disc or sheet, and the like. In one embodiment, the wrapping paper is provided in the form of a bag, convenient pack or box which can receive food for storage or further processing, wherein a convenient pack in the sense of the present invention is a folded pouch or wrap in which food can be placed and processed. The size of the bag, the convenience pack, the box or any other container into which the food is put can be appropriately selected. In another embodiment, the wrapper may form a container, such as a bag or box having a paper-folding opening (origami opening).

Depending on the method of manufacture, the wrapper of the present invention may have varying flexibility and stiffness depending on the intended use. In one embodiment of the invention, the wrapper is relatively flexible so that any shape and type of food product can be wrapped in a tight manner. Furthermore, the flexibility of the wrapper paper can be adjusted by moistening the paper. Depending on the humidity, the flexibility is made to vary. The person skilled in the art will know the humidity to obtain the necessary flexibility. The flexibility of the wrapper paper may also be affected by its basis weight. Generally, the higher the weight, the less flexible the wrapper will be. Furthermore, flexibility can be affected by the raw materials used to make the wrapper, as some plants can provide more original flexibility than others. For example, there are different amounts of cellulose in the plant material, which results in different flexibility of the wrapper. The flexibility can also be adjusted by the amount and quality of the added materials (such as wood pulp, cellulose and its derivatives, etc.) during the manufacturing process. Thus, the flexibility of the wrapper can be adjusted by a combination of the above features.

In one embodiment of the invention, the food product is used in raw form, i.e. it is used in its original form without any further treatment.

The food product may optionally be pre-treated before it is wrapped or packaged (as described below) with the wrapper of the present invention. In one embodiment, pre-processing the food product means enhancing the ability to receive the aroma, flavor and/or taste provided by the wrapper of the present invention. For example, the food may be pierced, pressed, scraped, cut, softened, etc., using any conventional means, such as, but not limited to, forks, knives, meat tenderizers (meattailerizers), etc.

In another embodiment of the invention, the pre-processed food product relates to, but is not limited to, cooked, salted (salting), smoked (smoking) and/or fermented food products. The preparation may depend on the specific food product that should be prepared.

The invention especially includes the use of the wrapper of the invention for cooking applications such as cooking, frying, roasting, grilling, baking and/or pickling, for example as conventional mixed flavours, as described in the present specification. In particular, the present invention includes the use of the wrapper of the present invention as a food or food product, for cooking or cooking purposes, or for flavour applications and the like, as described hereinabove and in the following description and examples.

In one embodiment of the present invention, the wrapping paper is used for pickling foods. Generally, marination is the process of contacting the food with a composition of herbs and/or spices to further flavor the food. In the present invention, the curing process is achieved by wrapping the food with the wrapping paper of the present invention or by inserting the food into a bag formed by the wrapping paper or any other type of wrapping paper. Depending on the degree of curing, the food may be wrapped for a specific period of time. For example, the food product may be wrapped for several minutes, such as about 1, about 2,
